ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got to try to analyze more complex, authentic material in Chinese.

Outside of the knowledge gained from the topics discussed in class, the best skill developed from this course were the improvements in my writing in that I more properly learned when to use certain phrases transitions in writing. Additionally, I improved my sentence structure by shifting from long, occasionally incomprehensible sentences to having better sentence variety.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 
students always received detailed feedback, small setting improved the learning experience 

Weaknesses: 
students had a wide range of Chinese level, so reading material was not always adequate

The topics discussed were very new to me and my peers, so in addition to improving our writing and presentation skills from this course, we also got to learn about many specific, interesting events in Chinese history along with aspects of Chinese culture. However, I do feel that homework can become repetitive because for much of the semester, we either had Perusall reading assignments or Playposit video assignments that become dry without greater assignment variety.  That being said, the end of the semester turned more towards presentations and projects, which I appreciated. My lone suggestion would be to scatter presentations throughout the semester in order to have a more consistent diversity of assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are looking for a flexible course and already have a high level of Chinese, I'd recommend it! For students looking for some more guidance and language instruction, I'd say look for a course that has a longer history within the department.

As the topics discussed in class are predetermined and are quite niche, I would suggest any student who is considering the course to look at the syllabus before confirming their enrollment. Although many topics are unique, they could be disengaging or mundane to students depending on their interests, so I would advise to avoid the course if the topics do not pique one's interest and/or curiosity.
